# Unit 09: Critical Points

In single variable calc, we call $c \in R$ a critical value of $f$ if $f'(c)=0$ or $f'(c)$ is undefined. These values are often used to find local extrema.

A local maximum in multi-variable is exactly what you would think of:
In the neighbourhood around a local max, no other point yeilds a higher value of $f$. Likewise for min. Pretty obvious, but how do we find/prove these points?

!!! note Theorem
If $(a,b)$ is a local max or min of $f$. then each partial derivative is either equal to zero or does not exist.
!!!

This leads to the definition of a critical point:

!!! abstract Definition
A point $(a, b)$ in the domain of $f(x,y)$ is called a **critical point** of $f$ if:
![82308da5.png](82308da5-kl2t9530.png)
!!!

All local maxima/minima are critical points, but not all critical points are local maxima/minima.

![68dfad0e.png](68dfad0e-kl2t9530.png)


!!! note Definition: Quadratic Form
A function $Q$ of the form
$$Q(u,v) = a_{11}u^2+2a_{12}uv+a_{22}v^2$$

where the $a$s are constants, is called a quadratic form on $\mathbb{R}^2$.
![4074fc75.png](4074fc75-kl2t952z.png)

![7ca2ce75.png](7ca2ce75-kl2t9530.png)

![a9586b89.png](a9586b89-kl2t9530.png)

Remember, in a matrix 
$$
A = 
\begin{bmatrix}
a & b \\
c & d
\end{bmatrix}
,
det(A) = ad - bc
$$
!!!

Before continuing, note that if we're close to a critical point $(a,b)$, $f_x(a,b) = 0 = f_y(a,b)$. This means that we can rearrange the second degree taylor polynomial as: 
$$ f(x,y) - f(a,b) \approx \frac{1}{2}(f_{xx}(a,b)(x-a)^2 + 2f_{xy}(a,b)(x-a)(y-b) + f_{yy}(a,b)(y-b)^2)$$

The expression on the RHS is a quadratic form, with $u=x-a, yv=y-b$. The associated matrix is the Hessian matrix of $f$ at $(a,b)$:
$$Hf(a,b) = \begin{bmatrix} f_{xx}(a,b) & f_{xy}(a,b) \\f_{xy}(a,b) & f_{yy}(a,b) \end{bmatrix}
$$

![6ea3b25c.png](6ea3b25c-kl2t9530.png)

!!! caution Degenerate Critical points
Lmao degenerates. Ok I'm done.
Note that the second partial derivatives test is inconclusive if the hessian matrix is semidefinite. In this case, we say that the critical point $(a,b)$ is degenerate. In order to classify the critical point, we need to find the sign of $f(x,y)-f(a,b)$ in the neighbourhood around $(a,b)$. Basically, if the neighbourhood contains positive and negative values, we have a saddle point. Else, if it only contains positive values, we've got a local min. Else, we've got a local max.
!!!
